{
  "article_text": [
    "we introduce a self - adjoint ( c*- ) operator algebra algebra @xmath0 associated with a dynamical system on a metric graph .",
    "the system is governed by the wave equation and controlled from the boundary vertices .",
    "algebra @xmath0 is generated by the so - called _ eikonals _ , which are the self - adjoint operators related with reachable sets of the system .",
    "a structure of reachable sets and the algebra is the main subject of the paper .",
    "we show that @xmath0 is a direct sum of `` elementary blocks '' .",
    "each block is an operator ( sub)algebra , the operators multiplying @xmath2-valued functions by continuous matrix - valued functions of special kind .",
    "the eikonal algebra is determined by the boundary dynamical and/or spectral inverse data up to isometric isomorphism .",
    "it is an inspiring fact , which shows promise of its possible applications to inverse problems .",
    "in particular , one can hope to extract information about geometry of the graph from the algebra spectrum @xmath3 .",
    "such a technique works well on manifolds @xcite , @xcite , @xcite .",
    "the paper develops an algebraic version of the _ boundary control method _ in inverse problems @xcite , @xcite@xcite .",
    "our approach reveals some new and hopefully prospective relations between inverse problems on graphs and c*-algebras .      in more detail",
    ", we deal with the dynamical system @xmath4\\\\ & u|_{t=0}=u_t|_{t=0}=0 & & { \\rm in}\\,\\ , \\omega\\\\ & u = f & & { \\rm on \\,}\\",
    ", \\gamma \\times [ 0,t]\\,,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath5 is a finite compact metric graph , @xmath6 is the set of its boundary vertices ; @xmath7 is the laplace operator in @xmath5 defined on @xmath8 , which is a class of smooth functions satisfying the kirchhoff conditions at the interior vertices ; @xmath9 ; @xmath10 is a _",
    "boundary control_. a solution @xmath11 describes a wave initiated at @xmath6 by the control @xmath10 and propagating into @xmath5 .    with the system one associates the",
    "_ reachable sets _",
    "@xmath12\\right ) , { \\rm supp\\,}f \\in \\gamma \\times [ 0,t]\\ } \\quad \\gamma \\in \\gamma,\\ , 0\\leqslant s \\leqslant t.\\ ] ] let @xmath13 be the orthogonal projection in @xmath14 onto @xmath15 .",
    "a self - adjoint operator @xmath16 is called an _ eikonal _ ( corresponding to the boundary vertex @xmath17 ) .",
    "choose a subset @xmath18 .",
    "eikonal algebra _",
    "@xmath19 is defined as the minimal norm - closed c*-subalgebra of the bounded operator algebra @xmath20 , which contains all @xmath21 as @xmath22 .",
    "we provide the characteristic description of the sets @xmath15 and projections @xmath13 . as a result",
    ", we clarify how the eikonals @xmath21 act .",
    "thereafter , a structure of the eikonal algebra is revealed , and we arrive at the main result : the algebra is represented in the form of a finite direct sum @xmath23 where @xmath24 are the so - called _",
    "block algebras_. each @xmath24 is isometrically isomorphic to a subalgebra @xmath25 ; { \\mathbb r}^{m_j}\\right)\\right)$ ] generated by the operators , which multiply elements of @xmath26 ; { \\mathbb r}^{m_j}\\right)$ ] ( vector - valued functions of @xmath27 $ ] ) by the matrix - functions of the form @xmath28 . here",
    "each @xmath29 is a _ constant _ projecting matrix ; @xmath30 is a diagonal matrix , its diagonal elements being the _ linear functions _ of the form @xmath31 with @xmath32 $ ] .",
    "these functions are continuous , and , hence , we have @xmath33 ; { \\mathbb m}^{m_j}\\right)\\,,\\ ] ] where the latter is the algebra of continuous real @xmath34 - matrix valued functions on @xmath35 $ ] .      @xmath36algebra @xmath19 associated with a graph",
    "is a straightforward analog of the eikonal algebras associated with a riemannian manifold : see @xcite , @xcite .",
    "these algebras possess two principal features , which enable one to apply them to solving inverse problems on manifolds :    1 .",
    "the eikonal algebra is determined ( up to isometric isomorphism ) by dynamical and/or spectral boundary inverse data 2 .",
    "its spectrum is , roughly speaking , identical to the manifold .    by this",
    ", one can solve the problem of reconstruction of the manifold via its inverse data by the scheme @xcite@xcite : @xmath37 it is so effective application , which has motivated to extend this approach to inverse problems on graphs .",
    "the hope was that a graph seems to be a simpler object than a manifold of arbitrary dimension and topology .",
    "surprisingly , the latter turns out to be an illusion .",
    "first of all , in contrast to the eikonal algebras on manifolds of continuous functions ] , the algebra @xmath19 is _ noncommutative_. by this , in the general case , its spectrum @xmath38 endowed with the jacobson topology is a _ non - haussdorff _ space . hence , @xmath38 is by no means identical to the ( metric ) graph @xmath5 , so that property 2 fails",
    ".    however , property 1 does hold . also , the known examples show that representation ( [ main result ] ) and structure of the spectrum @xmath38 reflect some features of the graph geometry",
    ". therefore , an attempt to extract information on @xmath5 from the eikonal algebra and , eventually , to recover @xmath5 seems quite reasonable .",
    "hopefully , our paper is a step towards this goal .",
    "@xmath36 in view of big volume of the paper , we omit the proofs of some technical propositions .",
    "@xmath36this work is supported by grants rfbr 11 - 01 - 00407a and spbgu + 11.38.63.2012 , 6.38.670.2013 .",
    "we are grateful to the university of kyoto and personally prof .",
    "yu.iso for kind support of our collaboration .",
    "we thank i.v.kubyshkin for the help in computer graphics .",
    "let @xmath39 be finite intervals , each interval being regarded as a subspace of the metric space @xmath40 with the distance @xmath41 . the set @xmath42 endowed with the metric @xmath43",
    "is called a ( standard ) _ @xmath44-star _",
    "( see fig.1a ) .",
    "note that a 2-star is evidently isometric to the interval @xmath45 .",
    "a compact connected metric space @xmath5 with the metric @xmath46 is said to be a _ homogeneous metric graph _ if the following is fulfilled :    * @xmath47 , where @xmath48 , @xmath49 are the _ edges _ ; @xmath50 , @xmath51 are the _ interior vertices _ ; @xmath52 , @xmath53 are the _ boundary vertices _ , @xmath54 * each @xmath49 is isometric to a finite interval @xmath55 + [ conv 1 ] in what follows , we assume that the isometries ( _ parametrizations _ ) @xmath56 are fixed and write @xmath57 for a function @xmath58 on @xmath5 restricted to the edge @xmath49 .",
    "+ so , for @xmath59 one has @xmath60 . *",
    "every @xmath61 has a neighborhood ( in @xmath5 ) isometric to an @xmath62 with @xmath63 or @xmath64 , the number @xmath65 being called a _ multiplicity _ of @xmath66 .",
    "the vertices of multiplicity @xmath67 constitute the set @xmath68 .",
    "the vertices of multiplicity @xmath69 form the _ boundary _ @xmath6 .",
    "+ as was noted above , 2-stars are isometric to intervals ( edges ) . by this",
    ", they do not take part in further considerations .",

    "the characteristic set can be regarded as a space - time graph ; fig.2 illustrates the case @xmath98 .",
    "such a graph is also a metric space : it is endowed with the length element @xmath99 i.e. , for the close points @xmath100 $ ] one has @xmath101^{1\\over 2}$ ] . for arbitrary points , the distance @xmath102 is defined as the length of the shortest curves lying in @xmath84 $ ] and connecting the points .",

    "a possible way is to use a smooth regularization @xmath158 and then understand @xmath157 as a relevant limit of the classical solutions @xmath159 as @xmath160 .",
    "such a limit turns out to be a space - time distribution on @xmath161 $ ] of the class @xmath162 ( see , e.g. , @xcite ) .",
    "the distribution @xmath157 is called a _",
    "fundamental _ solution to ( [ graph 1])([graph 4 ] ) ( corresponding to the given @xmath17 ) .",
    "it describes the wave initiated by an instantaneous source supported at @xmath17 .",
    "consider its properties in more detail ; all of them are well known . recall that @xmath163 is the distance in @xmath5 .",
    "let @xmath76 be the edge incident to @xmath17 and parametrised by @xmath164 .",
    "let @xmath165 be the second vertex incident to @xmath76 .",

    "this evidently leads to the representation @xmath169 where @xmath170 belongs to @xmath76 and satisfies @xmath171 , @xmath172 is the dirac measure supported at @xmath173 .",
    "it means that the @xmath174-singularity , which is injected into the graph from @xmath17 , moves along @xmath76 towards @xmath118 with velocity @xmath69 ( see fig.3a ) .      at the moment",
    "@xmath175 the singularity reaches @xmath118 and then passes through @xmath118 .",
    "a simple analysis using ( [ kirchhoff laws ] ) and ( [ string eqn ] ) provides @xmath176 as @xmath177 is small ( namely , @xmath178 ) , where @xmath179 belongs to @xmath180 and satisfies @xmath181 . the function ( _ amplitude _ ) @xmath182 is @xmath183 hence , in passing through @xmath118 , the singularity splits onto @xmath184 parts ( singularities ) , the first one is reflected back into @xmath76",
    ", the others are injected into the other @xmath185 edges @xmath180 incident to @xmath118 .",
    "the reflected singularity has the negative amplitude .",
    "the process is illustrated by fig.3b .",
    "note that the ` conservation law ' @xmath186 is valid , so that the total amplitude after the passage through @xmath118 is equal to the amplitude of the incident singularity .",
    "in what follows , we refer to ( [ passing v])([conservation law ] ) as a _",
    "splitting rule_.      let @xmath187 be a boundary vertex nearest to @xmath118 : @xmath188 ( may be @xmath189 ) , so that @xmath190 holds .",
    "let @xmath180 be the edge incident to @xmath191 .",
    "as @xmath192 , one of the singularities , which have appeared as a result of passing through @xmath118 ( and , perhaps , through another vertices or reflected from @xmath118 back to @xmath17 ) , approaches to @xmath191 ( see fig.3c ) . then this singularity is reflected from @xmath191 . a simple analysis with the use of the condition @xmath193 leads to the representation @xmath194 where @xmath195 satisfies @xmath196 .",
    "thus , as a result of reflection from a boundary vertex , the singularity moves _ from _ it and changes the sign of the amplitude ( see fig.3d ) .",
    "this is a _ reflection rule_.    the splitting and reflection rules , along with superposition principle ( linearity of the system ) , uniquely determine the fundamental solution @xmath157 for all @xmath197 .",
    "let us list some of its well - known properties .",

    "[ graph 1])([graph 4 ] ) , a set of waves @xmath291 is said to be _ reachable _ ( from the boundary at the moment @xmath292 ) . on graphs , @xmath293 is a closed subspace in @xmath130 .",
    "its structure is of principal importance for many applications , in particular to inverse problems : see @xcite - @xcite , @xcite .    by ( [ f = sum",
    "f gamma ] ) , we have @xmath294 ( algebraic sum ) , where @xmath295 are the sets reachable from single boundary vertices .    by ( [ steady state ] ) , to study @xmath296 is to study @xmath297 , and we deal mainly with the latter set .",
    "its structure will be described in detail .",
    "however , the description requires certain preliminary considerations in 2.4.2  2.4.4 .",
    "we say two different points @xmath298 of @xmath274 to be _ neighbors _ and write @xmath299 , if either @xmath300 or @xmath301 ( equivalently : either @xmath302 or @xmath303 ) .",
    "we write @xmath304 if there are @xmath305 such that @xmath306 . as is easy to check",
    ", @xmath307 is an equivalence on the hydra . for an @xmath308",
    ", its equivalence class is called a _ lattice _ and denoted by @xmath309$]$ ] as a subset of @xmath274 but not as an element of the factor - set @xmath310 . ] .    for a @xmath311 we set @xmath312:=\\bigcup_{l \\in b}{\\cal l}[l ] \\subset h^t_\\gamma.\\ ] ]    we omit simple proofs of the following facts , which can be derived from the above - accepted definitions :    * for any @xmath311 , one has @xmath313\\right)\\right ) = \\rho^{-1}\\left(\\rho\\left({\\cal l}[b]\\right)\\right ) = { \\cal l}[b]$ ] * the operation @xmath314 $ ] satisfies the kuratovski axioms : + ( i)(_extensiveness _ ) @xmath315 \\supset b$ ] , + ( ii)(_idempotency _ ) @xmath316={\\cal l}[b]$ ] + ( iii)(_additivity _ ) @xmath317={\\cal l}[b']\\cup { \\cal l}[b'']$ ] + and , hence , is a topological closure .",
    "more precisely , there is a unique topology on the hydra , in which the closure coincides with @xmath318 ( see , e.g. , @xcite ) .",
    "* each @xmath309 $ ] is a finite set ; it is a closure of the single point set @xmath319 in the above mentioned topology .",
    "any point @xmath320 $ ] determines the whole set @xmath309 $ ] .    for a point @xmath272 } \\backslash \\gamma$ ] , define its _ determination set _ by @xmath321\\,:=\\,\\pi\\left({\\cal l}[\\pi^{-1}(x)]\\right)\\,\\subset \\omega\\,.\\ ] ] the _ alternating property _ holds : for @xmath322 , one has either @xmath323=\\lambda_\\gamma^t[x']$ ] or @xmath323\\cap\\lambda_\\gamma^t[x']=\\emptyset$ ] .",
    "determination set @xmath323 $ ] consists of the heads of the delayed hydras @xmath324 , which satisfy @xmath325\\right)$ ] .",
    "it is the hydras , which enter in representation ( [ value of u^f 1 ] ) .",
    "on fig.5 ,    * @xmath326 $ ] is the point of @xmath274 above @xmath228 , @xmath327=\\{p\\}$ ] * @xmath328 $ ] is the grey points on @xmath274 , @xmath329=\\{q_1 , q_2 , q_3 , q_4 , q_5\\}$ ] * @xmath330 $ ] is the black points on @xmath274 , @xmath331=\\{r_1 , r_2 , r_3\\}$ ] .",
    "return to representation ( [ value of u^f 1 ] ) and modify it as follows .",
    "let @xmath332\\right)=\\{t_i\\}_{i=1}^n,\\,\\,\\,0\\leqslant t_1<t_2<\\dots < t_n\\leqslant t\\,,\\ ] ] so that @xmath333\\right)$ ] .",
    "introduce the functions @xmath334 \\to { \\mathbb r}$ ] , @xmath335 and call them _ amplitude vectors_.",
    "so , the set @xmath323 $ ] is endowed with amplitude vectors @xmath336 .",
    "let @xmath337)$ ] be euclidean space of functions on @xmath323 $ ] with the standard product @xmath338 } \\alpha(h)\\,\\beta(h)\\,.\\ ] ] by @xmath339 $ ] we denote the subspace in @xmath340)$ ] generated by amplitude vectors : @xmath341\\,:=\\,{\\rm span\\,}\\left\\{\\alpha^{t , t_1 } , \\dots , \\alpha^{t , t_n}\\right\\}\\,.\\ ] ]    now , we are able to clarify the meaning of definition ( [ lambda = pi(l ) ] ) and the term `` determination set '' . in accordance with ( [ value of u^f 1 ] ) , given @xmath342 , for all @xmath343 $ ] the values @xmath344 _ are determined _ by hydras @xmath324 , whose heads constitute @xmath323 $ ] .",

    "the question arises : what are the bounds for such variations ? in this section the answer is given .",
    "* critical points.*recall that the corner points on the complete hydra @xmath206 are introduced at the end of 2.2.5 . dealing with @xmath274",
    ", it is also convenient to assign its top @xmath354 to corner points .",
    "so , we say a space - time point @xmath355 to be a _ corner point _ if it is a corner point of @xmath206 or belongs to the top of @xmath274 .",
    "the set of corner points is denoted by @xmath356 .",
    "note that , for any vertex @xmath357\\cap \\overline{\\omega^t[\\gamma]}$ ] , its pre - image @xmath358 consists of corner points .",
    "introduce the lattice @xmath359\\,,$ ] which is a finite set of points on @xmath274 .",
    "this lattice divides hydra @xmath274 so that the set @xmath360 $ ] consists of a finite number of open space - time intervals , which do not contain corner points . by the latter , on these intervals the amplitude @xmath361 takes _ constant values_.    points of the set @xmath362\\right)\\,\\subset \\overline{\\omega^t[\\gamma]}\\ ] ]",
    "are called _",
    "critical points divide neighborhood @xmath363}$ ] into parts .",
    "namely , the set @xmath363}\\backslash \\theta^t_\\gamma\\,$ ] is a collection of open intervals , each interval lying into an edge of @xmath5 , whereas the critical points are the endpoints of these intervals .",
    "we refer to this collection as a _ partition _ @xmath348 .    * families and cells.*intervals of partition @xmath348 are joined in the _ families _ as follows .",
    "let @xmath364 be critical points such that the interval @xmath365c , c^\\prime[\\,\\ , \\subset e$ ] contains no critical points .",
    "this means that @xmath366 .",
    "as one can easily see , the preimage @xmath367 consists of a finite number of connected components .",
    "each component is a ( space - time ) interval on @xmath274 of the same ( space - time ) length @xmath368 ( see ( [ metric on char set ] ) ) , the interval being free of corner points . by the latter ,",
    "the same is valid for the lattice @xmath369 $ ] : it is also a finite collection of open intervals on @xmath274 of length @xmath370 , which do not contain corner points .    as a consequence , the set @xmath371 \\right ) \\supset \\omega\\ ] ] turns out to be a finite collection of open intervals @xmath372}\\backslash \\theta^t_\\gamma$ ] ( with @xmath114 among them ) of the same length : @xmath373    we say this collection to be a _ family _",
    ", intervals @xmath374 are called _ cells _ of @xmath375 .    comparing definitions ( [ lambda = pi(l ) ] ) and ( [ family phi ] ) , ( [ phi = sum of cells ] ) , one can easily conclude the following . for any @xmath376 , the set @xmath323 \\subset \\phi$ ]",

    "define a vector @xmath628)$ ] by @xmath629 * redesign the system @xmath630 by the schmidt process ( see ( [ schmidt ] ) ) and get the system @xmath631 .",
    "the amplitude subspace is @xmath632\\ , : = \\,{\\rm span\\,}\\check \\beta^t_{\\gamma , \\phi } \\subset { \\bf l}_2(\\lambda^t_\\sigma[x])\\,.\\ ] ]        recall that @xmath430 projects in @xmath130 onto @xmath428 . repeating the arguments , which have led to representations ( [ p via q phi ] ) and ( [ q phi via beta ] )",
    ", one can modify them to the following form relevant to the complete hydra @xmath585 : @xmath635 where @xmath636}\\,,\\ , \\beta^{t , i}_{\\gamma , \\phi}\\right\\rangle\\ ,   \\beta^{t , i}_{\\gamma , \\phi}(x)\\ , ,    & x \\in \\phi\\\\0 , & x \\in \\omega \\backslash \\phi\\end{cases } \\,.\\ ] ]    quite analogously , a relevant version of representations ( [ eikonal 2 ] ) and ( [ eikonal ] ) takes the form @xmath637 where @xmath638}\\,,\\ , \\beta^{t , i}_{\\gamma , \\phi}\\right\\rangle\\ , \\beta^{t , i}_{\\gamma , \\phi}(x)\\ , ,    & x \\in \\phi\\\\0 , & x \\in \\omega \\backslash \\phi\\end{cases } \\,.\\ ] ]    fix a @xmath22 and choose a family @xmath639 ; recall that the number @xmath352 is defined in ( [ sum of ii general ] ) . parametrize @xmath375 by ( [ parametrization x(r ) ] ) , ( [ def u phi ] ) : @xmath640 . denote @xmath641 where @xmath642 is either @xmath566 or @xmath567 . note that @xmath643 is the matrix of the projection @xmath644 in @xmath447 onto @xmath645 . in this notation , the first line in the right hand side of ( [ eikonal 2 general sigma ] ) is @xmath646\\ , \\vec{y}(r)\\ , , \\quad r \\in ( 0 , \\delta_\\phi)\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,(\\gamma \\in \\sigma)\\,,\\ ] ] which is just a relevant form of ( [ eikonal 3 ] ) .",
    "a key feature of representations ( [ eikonal 2 general sigma ] ) and ( [ eikonal 3 general sigma ] ) is the following .",
    "they represent eikonals @xmath21 in the form , which is common to all the vertices @xmath22 and available for any family @xmath375 of partition @xmath583 of the complete hydra @xmath585 .      in accordance with ( [ partition pi sigma ] ) , we have the decomposition @xmath647\\rangle\\,=\\,\\oplus \\sum \\limits_{\\phi \\in \\pi^t_\\sigma}{\\cal h}\\langle\\phi\\rangle\\,,\\ ] ] which reduces each eikonal @xmath21 for @xmath22 : @xmath648 ( compare with ( [ h[omega^t]= sum h < phi > ] ) and ( [ eikonal ] ) ) .",
    "each part @xmath649 acts in the subspace @xmath650 by ( [ eikonal 2 general sigma ] ) or , equivalently , by ( [ eikonal 3 general sigma ] ) in the parametrized form .      by ( [ eikonal 3 general sigma ]",
    ") , each @xmath653 is isometrically isomorphic to the subalgebra @xmath654 generated by the operators , which multiply elements ( vector - functions ) @xmath655 by the matrix - functions @xmath656(@xmath22 ) .",
    "these functions are continuous,$ ] ] and hence we have @xmath657 ; { \\mathbb m}^{m(\\phi)}\\right)\\,,\\ ] ] where the latter is the algebra of continuous real @xmath658 - matrix valued functions on @xmath659 $ ] .        as we noted in introduction",
    ", algebra @xmath19 is noncommutative .",
    "the reason is that the matrix projections @xmath661 ( in @xmath662 onto @xmath663 ) corresponding to different @xmath664 do not have to commute . as a result ,",
    "eikonal parts @xmath665 and @xmath666 do not commute as @xmath667 , so that the block - algebra @xmath653 turns out to be noncommutative .    moreover , in a sense , the eikonal algebra on a graph is _ strongly _ noncommutative .",
    "we mean the following . in the maxwell dynamical system on a riemannian manifold ,",
    "a straightforward analog of @xmath19 is also a noncommutative algebra but its factor over the ideal of compact operators turns out to be commutative @xcite ( and , moreover , isometric to the algebra @xmath668 ) .",
    "this may be referred to as a _ weak _ noncommutativity . on graphs ,",
    "it is definitely not the case : simple examples show that no factorization eliminates noncommutativity of a generic block - algebra .",
    "a _ spectrum _ @xmath38 of the algebra @xmath19 is the set of its primitive ideals endowed with the jacobson topology ( see @xcite , @xcite ) . by ( [ basic ] )",
    ", one has @xmath669 so that to study a structure of @xmath38 is to analyze @xmath670 . in the general case of arbitrary graph ,",
    "such an analysis is an open and difficult problem .",
    "here we discuss some `` experimental material '' provided by examples on simple graphs .    in the known examples , in accordance with ( [ structure of e ] ) , one encounters @xmath671 ; { \\mathbb m}^{m}\\right)\\,\\big|\\,\\,l_0[b(0)]=0,\\,\\,l_1\\left[b(\\delta)\\right]=0\\right\\}\\,,\\ ] ] where @xmath672=0 $ ] and @xmath673=0 $ ] are the `` linear - type '' conditions , which can be ( or not be ) imposed on elements @xmath674 .",
    "for instance , at @xmath675 there may be @xmath676 as is seen from ( [ structure of blocs ] ) , the `` massive '' part of the spectrum @xmath670 ( and @xmath38 : see ( [ spec e= sum spec b ] ) ) consists of the ideals of the form @xmath677 in the mean time , noncommutativity implies that the ( topologized ) spectrum @xmath670 is not necessarily a hausdorff space : it may contain the clusters .",
    "we say a subset @xmath678 to be a _ cluster _ , if its points are not separable , i.e. , for any point @xmath679 and arbitrary neighborhood @xmath680 one has @xmath681 . in examples , clusters do appear as a consequence of kirschhoff laws ( [ kirchhoff laws ] ) . by them , the amplitude vectors , which correspond to different families @xmath682 are not quite independent .",
    "it is the dependence , which implies the conditions like ( [ linear conditions l m ] ) . in the known examples",
    ", the clusters in @xmath38 do appear if @xmath683\\cap \\omega[\\gamma^\\prime]\\ni v$ ] occurs for the different @xmath684 and an interior vertex @xmath116 .",
    "* by the latter , it would be reasonable to suggest that the number of interior vertices @xmath685 and the number of clusters @xmath686 are related through an inequality : presumably , @xmath687 holds . since @xmath686 is a topological invariant of spectrum @xmath38 , this relation could be helpful in inverse problems on graphs , in which the inverse data do determine the eikonal algebra @xmath688 up to an isometric isomorphism ( see @xcite@xcite ) .",
    "therefore , the data determine the spectrum @xmath38 up to a homeomorphism , and the external observer , which possesses the data , can hope for getting information about the graph from the spectrum . *",
    "an intriguing question is whether another geometric characteristics of the graph ( number of edges and cycles , multiplicity of interior vertices , etc ) are related with topological invariants of the spectrum @xmath689 .",
    "a prospective ( but rather far ) goal is _ to recover the graph _ from the boundary inverse data via its eikonal algebra .",
    "m.i.belishev . on the boundary controllability of dynamical system governed by the wave equation on a class of graphs ( trees ) . , 308 : 2347 , 2004 ( in russian ) ; english translation : _ j. math . sciences _ , v. 132 , no 1 , 2006 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> an operator c*-algebra @xmath0 associated with a dynamical system on a metric graph is introduced . </S>",
    "<S> the system is governed by the wave equation and controlled from boundary vertices . </S>",
    "<S> algebra @xmath0 is generated by the so - called _ eikonals _ , which are self - adjoint operators related with reachable sets of the system . </S>",
    "<S> its structure is the main subject of the paper . </S>",
    "<S> we show that @xmath0 is a direct sum of `` elementary blocks '' . </S>",
    "<S> each block is an algebra of operators , which multiply @xmath1-valued functions by continuous matrix - valued functions of special kind . </S>",
    "<S> the eikonal algebra is determined by the boundary inverse data . </S>",
    "<S> this shows promise of its possible applications to inverse problems .    </S>",
    "<S> * msc : * 46lxx , 34b45 , 35qxx , 35r30    </S>",
    "<S> * key words : * graph of strings , controllability , reachable sets , self - adjoint operator algebras , inverse problems    * short title : * a c*-algebra associated with a graph </S>"
  ]
}
